title: 113_s714
content: The Act is titled the "Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2013" and includes definitions. The "Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2013" defines terms such as "agency" and "covered civil action" related to compelling agency action or challenging delays in regulatory actions affecting private individuals or government entities. The "Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2013" defines terms related to consent decrees and settlement agreements in covered civil actions, including those affecting private individuals or government entities. The "Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2013" covers civil actions and settlement agreements that require agency action related to regulatory actions affecting private individuals or government entities. SEC. 3. CONSENT DECREE AND SETTLEMENT REFORM. In covered civil actions, the agency must publish the notice of intent to sue and complaint online within 15 days of receiving them. Parties cannot request entry of a consent decree or settlement agreement until after specified proceedings. In covered civil actions, the court presumes that the interests of a person filing a motion to intervene would not be adequately represented by existing parties, subject to rebuttal. For State, local, or tribal governments filing a motion to intervene, the court considers whether the movant meets certain criteria. In covered civil actions, the court considers whether a movant administers jointly with an agency that is a defendant or administers an authority that would be preempted by the regulatory action. Settlement negotiations must be conducted through mediation or alternative dispute resolution programs. The court considers joint administration with an agency or preempted authority in covered civil actions. Settlement negotiations must be conducted through mediation or alternative dispute resolution programs. Covered consent decrees or settlement agreements must be published in the Federal Register and online 60 days before filing, including statutory basis and terms. The agency must accept public comment on covered consent decrees or settlement agreements, responding to comments received before submitting to the court. When submitting a proposed covered consent decree or settlement agreement to court, an agency must inform the court of the statutory basis, provide a summary of comments received, submit a certified index of the administrative record, and make the administrative record available. The court must include the certified index of the administrative record in the court record for a civil action, along with any documents listed in the index submitted by parties or amicus curiae. Agencies may hold public hearings after providing notice to consider entering into a proposed covered consent decree or settlement agreement. If an agency holds a public hearing for a proposed covered consent decree or settlement agreement, they must submit a summary and certified index of the proceedings to the court. The full hearing record will be included in the court record. When a decree or settlement agreement requires agency action by a specific date, the agency must inform the court of any outstanding regulatory actions, how the agreement would impact those actions, and why it is in the public interest. The Government must submit a certification to the court for any proposed covered consent decree or settlement agreement containing specific terms. The Attorney General or head of the agency must personally approve and sign the certification. The terms include converting discretionary authority of an agency into nondiscretionary duties. The curr_chunk discusses regulations, agency expenditures, budget commitments, seeking appropriations, and agency discretion limitations. The curr_chunk discusses terms in a covered settlement agreement that provide remedies for agency non-compliance, without interfering with the agency's authority to revise rules. The curr_chunk outlines rules for covered settlement agreements, including restrictions on agency expenditures and discretion. The curr_chunk discusses the review process by the court for covered consent decrees or settlement agreements, allowing amicus participation and reviewing deadlines. The court must review proposed covered consent decrees and settlement agreements to ensure they allow sufficient time and incorporate adequate procedures for agency compliance with relevant statutes and Executive orders governing rulemaking. Each agency must submit an annual report to Congress detailing civil actions, consent decrees, and settlement agreements, along with the statutory basis for each agreement. The agency must report annually to Congress on civil actions, consent decrees, and settlement agreements, including any awards of attorneys' fees or costs in resolved cases. SEC. 4. MOTIONS TO MODIFY CONSENT DECREES. If an agency seeks to modify a covered consent decree or settlement agreement because it is no longer in the public interest, the court will review the motion and agreement de novo. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to civil actions filed or consent decrees proposed after its enactment.
